'''ArtTactic''' is an art [[market research]] firm based in London <ref>Scott Reyburn,"Price Warning Issued Before $169 Million Warhol, Hirst Art Sale", 28/06/2010, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-27/price-warning-issued-before-169-million-warhol-hirst-art-sale.html], 09/08/2010</ref><ref>"About Us", [http://www.arttactic.com/Content/about-us], 09/08/2010</ref> founded by Anders Petterson in 2001.<ref>Colin Gleadell, "Art sales: Art blossoms in the desert", 07/10/2008, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/artsales/3561776/Art-sales-Art-blossoms-in-the-desert.html], 09/08/2010</ref> The company uses techniques similar to those used in the financial markets to analyze the art market and build up art [[market trends]].<ref>Anindita Ghose, "It’s important to educate clients on how the art market works", 20/08/2009, [http://www.livemint.com/2009/08/20215706/It8217s-important-to-educat.html], 09/08/2010</ref> Their services include market sector reports for both art mediums such as photography<ref>Colin Gleadell, "Art Sales: 'Don't always buy what you like'", 22/02/2010, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/artsales/7294206/Art-Sales-Dont-always-buy-what-you-like.html], 09/08/2010</ref> and regional sectors such as China,<ref>"Report Notes Emergence Of Mainland Chinese “Super-Collectors”, Strength Of Domestic Auction Houses, Strong Confidence In Contemporary Artists", {{cite web|url=http://www.jingdaily.com/en/culture/arttactics-new-chinese-art-market-report-highlights/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528173356/http://www.jingdaily.com/en/culture/arttactics-new-chinese-art-market-report-highlights/ |archivedate=2010-05-28 |df= }}, 09/08/2010</ref> auction analysis,<ref>Scott Reyburn, "Greedy Auction Sellers Endanger Fragile Recovery, Dealers Warn", 05/07/2010, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-04/greedy-auction-sellers-endanger-fragile-recovery-dealers-warn.html], 09/08/2010</ref> artist reports,<ref>Scott Reyburn, "Hirst Auction Is Crucial to Art-Market Confidence, Report Says", 01/09/2010, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=av4m03U._tF4], 09/08/2010</ref> and the ArtTactic confidence reports, which are surveys of the leading art market players and their sentiments and confidence towards individual artists and different segments of the art market.<ref>Scott Reyburn, "Contemporary Art Market Confidence Slumps 40%, Survey Shows", 24/01/2008, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ax8ss0p6.y6I], 09/08/2010</ref> There are confidence reports for US & Europe,<ref>Scott Reyburn, "Contemporary Art Market Confidence Slumps 40%, Survey Shows", 24/01/2008, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ax8ss0p6.y6I], 09/08/2010</ref> China,<ref>"New ArtTactic Survey Shows Confidence In Chinese Contemporary Art Market Is Back", 01/12/2009, {{cite web|url=http://www.jingdaily.com/en/culture/new-arttactic-survey-shows-confidence-in-chinese-contemporary-art-market-is-back/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609005100/http://www.jingdaily.com/en/culture/new-arttactic-survey-shows-confidence-in-chinese-contemporary-art-market-is-back/ |archivedate=2010-06-09 |df= }}, 09/08/2010</ref> India<ref>Anindita Ghose, "Upswing in Indian art market confidence", 14/11/2009, [http://www.livemint.com/2009/11/13002802/Upswing-in-Indian-art-market-c.html], 09/08/2010</ref> and South Asia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arttactic.com/product/south-asian-art-market-report-2017/|title=Research Report: South Asian Art Market 2017 - ArtTactic|newspaper=ArtTactic|access-date=2017-02-10|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== History == ArtTactic was founded in London by Anders Petterson in 2001. In 2004, ArtTactic organized Art Market Forum in conjunction with [[Frieze Art Fair]] and [[Zoo Art Fair]] in London.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnet.com/Magazine/news/artnetnews2/artnetnews10-14-04.asp|title=artnet.com Magazine News|website=www.artnet.com|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> Later that year, Petterson began lecturing on art as an asset class at [[Sotheby's Institute of Art]] in London. The following year, ArtTactic launched its first Art Market Confidence Survey for the US & European art market. In 2006, ArtTactic published an Artist Analysis Report on contemporary artist [[Richard Prince]], following a successful report on [[Damien Hirst]]. Two years later, ArtTactic published its first Indian Art Market report, presenting its findings at [[Art Dubai]]. In 2009, ArtTactic launched its weekly podcasts, hosted by Adam Green. In 2011, ArtTactic published an Artist Analysis Report on [[Andy Warhol]], which was presented in New York during the inaugural Artelligence Conference<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2011/04/14/andy-warhol-datapoints-of-the-day/|title=Andy Warhol datapoints of the day|last=Salmon|first=By Felix|website=Reuters Blogs|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> and the first edition of the Art & Finance Report, a co-production between [[Deloitte]] and ArtTactic. The next year, ArtTactic authored the first edition of the [[Hiscox]] Online Art Trade Report. In 2013, ArtTactic published an in-depth, updated Artist Analysis Report on the [[Damien Hirst]] market.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/hirstonomics-how-damien-hirst-became-a-cash-cow-again-8874714.html|title=Hirstonomics: How Damien Hirst became a cash cow again|date=2013-10-11|newspaper=The Independent|access-date=2017-02-10|language=en-GB}}</ref> Also that year, ArtTactic launches ArtForecaster and organizes its first public online forecasting competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c2e33f68-94a1-11e3-9146-00144feab7de|title=The Art Market: safe bets vs rising stars|website=Financial Times|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> Two years afterwards, ArtTactic's Art Market Outlook warns that the art market could start to cool.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.artmediaagency.com/99656/2015-the-year-that-the-bubble-bursts/|title=2015: The year that the bubble bursts? {{!}} AMA {{!}} Art Media Agency|website=en.artmediaagency.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> In 2016, ArtTactic began publishing ArtTactic Rawfacts, a weekly, monthly and quarterly report on auctions performances at [[Christie's]], [[Sotheby's]] and [[Phillips (auctioneers)|Phillips]], in addition to launching its first online course on Big Data and the Art Market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arttactic.teachable.com|title=ArtTactic LAB|website=arttactic.teachable.com|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> In 2017, ArtTactic published its inaugural South Asian Art Market Report in partnership with Rawlinson & Hunter, Constantine Cannon, Gurr Johns and W/R/B Underwriting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/anders-petterson/india-art-fair-an-antidote-to-the-increasing-influence-of-aucti/|title=India Art Fair: An Antidote To The Increasing Influence of Auctions|newspaper=Huffington Post India|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref>
== ArtTactic Podcast == In 2009, ArtTactic launched the ''ArtTactic [[Podcast]]'',<ref>Nazanin Lankarani, "Art Funds Feel a Revival as Economy Thaws Out", 09/04/2009 [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/05/business/global/05rinartfund.html]</ref> a weekly [[podcast]] hosted by Adam Green. The [[podcast]] features in-depth interviews with leading [[art market]] figures, focusing on topics such as [[art valuation|art market analysis]], [[art auction]]s, [[alternative investment|art investment funds]], [[art exhibition|art fairs]] and [[art finance|art financing]]. Past guests include [[Simon de Pury]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arttactic.com/podcast/simon-de-pury/|title=Simon is a London-based art dealer and art adviser.|newspaper=ArtTactic|access-date=2017-02-09|language=en-GB}}</ref> Richard Polsky,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arttactic.com/podcast/richard-polsky-richard-polsky-art-authentication/|title=Richard Polsky, author, dealer and founder of Richard Polsky|newspaper=ArtTactic|access-date=2017-02-09|language=en-GB}}</ref> Howard Rachofsky<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arttactic.com/podcast/howard-rachofsky-two-x-two/|title=Howard Rachofsky - TWO x TWO - ArtTactic|newspaper=ArtTactic|access-date=2017-02-09|language=en-GB}}</ref> and [[Matthew Slotover]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arttactic.com/podcast/matthew-slotover-frieze-art-fair-2/|title=Matthew Slotover - Frieze Art Fair - ArtTactic|newspaper=ArtTactic|access-date=2017-02-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Art & Finance Report == In 2011, ArtTactic began publishing the Art & Finance Report,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arttactic.com/categories/art-finance/|title=Art & Finance Archives - ArtTactic|website=ArtTactic|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> alongside [[Deloitte|Deloitte Luxembourg]], an annual report that assesses the developments in the art and finance industry.
== Online Art Trade Report == In 2013, ArtTactic launched the Online Art Trade Report,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arttactic.com/categories/online-art-market/|title=Online Art Market Archives - ArtTactic|website=ArtTactic|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> in collaboration with [[Hiscox]], an annual report that analyzes several trends and aspects of the emerging online art market.
== ArtTactic Forecaster == In 2014, ArtTactic introduced the [https://artforecaster.com ArtTactic Forecaster], an online platform that enables art market enthusiasts and professionals to compete against one another in predicting sales results for artworks upcoming at auction. In addition to a year-long competition, tournaments occur throughout the year surrounding major auction weeks in which top performing players earn awards such as art by contemporary artists including [[Damien Hirst]] and art market themed books. Players may compete in the Expert or Rookie League based on their past performance as well as their experience within the art world.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://arttactic.com ArtTactic]
[[Category:Business of visual arts]]

page.title: As a dog returns to his vomit, so a fool repeats his folly

revision.comment: /* Usage */more direct link, replaced: The Daily Telegraph (Australia) → The Daily Telegraph (Sydney) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
"'''As a dog returns to his vomit, so a fool repeats his folly'''" is an [[aphorism]] which appears in the [[Book of Proverbs]] in the [[Bible]] — [[s:Bible (King James)/Proverbs#26:11|Proverbs 26:11]] ({{Lang-he|כְּ֭כֶלֶב שָׁ֣ב עַל־קֵאֹ֑ו כְּ֝סִ֗יל שֹׁונֶ֥ה בְאִוַּלְתֹּֽו}} ''Kəḵeleḇ šāḇ ‘al-qê’ōw; kəsîl, šōwneh ḇə’iwwaltōw.''), also partially quoted in the [[New Testament]], [[2 Peter]] 2:22. It means that fools are stubbornly [[Rigidity (psychology)|inflexible]] and this is illustrated with the repulsive [[simile]] of the [[dog]] that eats its [[vomiting|vomit]] again, even though this may be poisonous. Dogs were considered [[unclean animals|unclean]] in Biblical times as they were commonly [[scavenger]]s of the dead and they appear in the Bible as repugnant creatures, symbolising evil.{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Lj8IXYthLgC|page=354|title=The Book of Proverbs: Chapters 15–31|author=Bruce K. Waltke|isbn=978-0-8028-2776-0|year=2005|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing}}{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PyUEAAAAMAAJ|title=Writing with a purpose|author=James McNab McCrimmon|page=144|isbn=978-0-395-17740-2|year=1973|publisher=Houghton Mifflin}}{{citation|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/brill/saa/1997/00000005/00000001/art00003|title=Dogs: God's Worst Enemies?|author=Sophia Menache|volume=5|issue=1|year=1997|pages=23–44|doi=10.1163/156853097X00204|journal=Society and Animals}} The reference to vomit indicates excessive indulgence and so also symbolises revulsion.{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5yz04U3SlSMC&pg=PA92 |year=2008 |title=Animal imagery in the book of Proverbs |isbn=978-90-04-16287-7 |author=Tova Forti |chapter=Dog and Fool}} The incorrigible nature of fools is further emphasised in [[s:Bible (King James)/Proverbs#27:22|Proverbs 27:22]], "Though you grind a fool in a [[mortar and pestle|mortar]], grinding them like grain with a pestle, you will not remove their folly from them."{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qjEYEjVVEosC|title=Dictionary of biblical imagery|author1=Leland Ryken |author2=Jim Wilhoit |author3=James C. Wilhoit |author4=Tremper Longman |author5=Colin Duriez |author6=Douglas Penney |author7=Daniel G. Reid |page=296|isbn=978-0-8308-1451-0|publisher=InterVarsity Press|year=1998}} In Proverbs, the "fool" represents a person lacking moral behavior or discipline, and the "wise" represents someone who behaves carefully and righteously. The modern association of these words with intellectual capacity is not in the original context. ==Development== The Greek translation in the [[Septuagint]] developed the idea, imbuing it with a sense of [[shame]] and [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]], "As when a dog goes to his own vomit and becomes abominable, so is a fool who returns in his wickedness to his own sin." This was due to the contemporary idea of the fool as [[Bad (ethics)#Christian theology|ungodly]].{{citation|title=Conceptual Stratification in LXX Prov 26,11: Toward Identifying the Tradents Behind the Aphorism |author=Tova Forti |journal=Zeitschrift für die Alttestamentliche Wissenschaft |volume=119 |issue=2 |pages=241–258 |issn=1613-0103 |doi=10.1515/ZAW.2007.019 |date=June 2007 |url=http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/ZAW.2007.019 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Usage== The [[Second Epistle of Peter]] refers to the proverb ([[s:Bible (King James)/2 Peter#2:22|2 Peter 2:22]]),{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oJcsAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA285 |page=285 |title=Notes, explanatory and practical, on the general epistles of James, Peter, John and Jude |author=Albert Barnes |year=1852}} "But it is happened unto them according to the true proverb, The dog is turned to his own vomit again; and the sow that was washed to her wallowing in the mire." [[Rudyard Kipling|Kipling]] cites this in his poem ''[[The Gods of the Copybook Headings]]'' as one of several classic examples of repeated folly:{{cquote|As it will be in the future, it was at the birth of Man
There are only four things certain since Social Progress began.
That the Dog returns to his Vomit and the Sow returns to her Mire,
And the burnt Fool's bandaged finger goes wabbling back to the Fire;}} The proverb is a favourite of the British politician [[Ken Livingstone]] who used it on the occasion of his failure to rejoin the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] in 2002.{{citation|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/livingstone-vents-his-fury-as-his-bid-to-rejoin-labour-fails-649295.html|title=Livingstone vents his fury as his bid to rejoin Labour fails|author=Paul Waugh|date=24 July 2002|publisher=The Independent}} It was also used on occasion in the [[Parliament of Australia]] by [[Paul Keating]], in reference to his political opponents.{{citation |title=The half wit, wisdom of a failed intellect | journal=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |date=Sep 26, 2006 |author=Piers Akerman |quote=In 1990, Paul Keating famously accused Wilson Tuckey of being "a dog returning to its own vomit" ...}} In the TV programme ''[[Endeavour (TV series)|Endeavour]]'' (the prequel to ''[[Inspector Morse (TV series)|Inspector Morse]]''), in the episode titled "Home," Endeavour returns to his family home to visit his sick father. He goes with his sister Joyce to a pub for a drink and the following is part of their conversation:
Joyce: "Why did you go back to Oxford?" Endeavour: "Oh! A policeman goes where he's sent." Joyce: "When I told Pop, he just said, ''''Proverbs 26:11'''.'" Endeavour: [Recognizing the verse] "Well I've many faults, God knows, but I try to draw the line at masochism. Besides, traditionally it's the killer that returns to the scene of the crime, not the... whatever I was."''Endeavour'', Season 1, Episode, 4 May 5th 2013.
==See also== *[[Sphex|Digger wasps and their habit of ''sphexishness'']] ==References== {{reflist|40em}} [[Category:Hebrew Bible words and phrases]] [[Category:New Testament words and phrases]] [[Category:Dogs in popular culture]] [[Category:Adages]] [[Category:Proverbs]] [[Category:Wisdom literature]] [[Category:Book of Proverbs]] [[Category:Vomiting]] [[Category:Animals in the Bible]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to animals]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
'''Atelier Viking''' is a studio and an [[artist-run initiative]] based in [[Douala]], [[Cameroon]].
Artist [[Viking Kanganyam|Viking Kanganyam André]] founded atelier Viking in March 1976 to promote contemporary art in Cameroon. The paucity of art galleries in Douala encouraged Kanganyam to create a space where artists could be trained and exhibited. Viking taught visual arts (painting, sculpture, graphic art, drawing and serygraphy) to small groups of students. Viking encouraged his students to explore the potentialities of all media and specifically the possibility of transforming and re-using materials found in loco. Concurrently to their activity of visual artists, they worked in advertising. Since 2001, Viking decided to devote his space mostly to exhibitions.
Atelier Viking is located in the neighbourhood of Bessengue, Rue Jamot face Garage Technique Auto, 100mt from Mobil Bonakouamuang. It collaborates with [[Art Wash]].
== Exhibitions and Events Organised by Atelier Viking == * Squat'art, Patrice Kemplo (2003) in collaboration with [[Art Wash]]; * Sweet Again, [[Koko Komégné]] (18 December 2002 - 4 January 2003); * [[Musoula Mo]], [[Guy Wouete]] and [[Daniel Seppo]] exhibiting 26 paintings and installations (2002); * Round table on selected themes: conviviality, solidarity and fraternity (2002); * Lecture Café with [[Alioum Moussa]], reading and debate on the art magazines and literature (March 2002); * Yann and Co: [[Yanne Queinnec]], [[Koko Komégné]], [[Kanganyam Viking]], [[Kouo Eyango]], [[Nyah Delord]], [[Massong Victor]], [[Bernarnd Baïfang]], [[Alium Moussa]] (May 2001).
== Bibliography == * Essombe Mouangué, ''L'Atelier Viking de Douala: un espace ouvert à toutes les sensibilités artistiques'' in "Africultures", 2002 [https://web.archive.org/web/20110519190406/http://www.africultures.com/index.asp?menu=revue_affiche_article&no=2634&rech=1] * Essombe Mouangué, ''Expositions à Douala: Koko Komégné, Kouoh Eyango, Martin Njombè II'' in "Africultures", 2003 [https://web.archive.org/web/20051028165830/http://www.africultures.com/index.asp?menu=revue_affiche_article&no=2773] * Giulia Paoletti, ''Cultural and artistic initiatives in Douala'' in ''Douala in Translation. A view of the city and its creative transformative potentials'', edited by Doual'art and iStrike Foundation, Episode Publishers, Rotterdam, 2007, pp. 243-247.
[[Category:Arts organizations based in Cameroon]] [[Category:Artist-run centres]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1976]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:A Cellier, H J Leslie, B C Stephenson.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Alfred Cellier]], H. J. Leslie and Stephenson, creators of ''[[Dorothy (opera)|Dorothy]]'']] '''Benjamin Charles Stephenson''' or '''B. C. Stephenson''' (1839 – 22 January 1906) was an English dramatist, lyricist and librettist. After beginning a career in the civil service, he started to write for the theatre, using the pen name "Bolton Rowe". He was author or co-author of several long-running shows of the [[Victorian era|Victorian]] theatre. His biggest hit was the [[comic opera]] ''[[Dorothy (opera)|Dorothy]]'', which set records for the length of its original run.
His writing collaborators included [[Clement Scott]] and [[Brandon Thomas]], and composers with whom he worked included [[Frederic Clay]], [[Alfred Cellier]] and [[Sir Arthur Sullivan]] with whom he wrote ''[[The Zoo]]'', which continues to be revived today.
==Life and career==
===Early years=== Stephenson, the son of Sir William Henry Stephenson, came from a family with a history of public service, both civil and military. His grandfather, also named [[Benjamin C. Stephenson|Benjamin Charles Stephenson]], was a [[Major-General (United Kingdom)|major-general]] and later one of the [[Commissioners of Woods and Forests]].<ref name=general>"Obituary, Major-Gen. Sir B. C. Stephenson", ''The Gentleman's Magazine'', Volume 12, July – December 1839, p. 317.</ref><ref>The general had two sons, one of whom, Frederick, followed him into the army and rose to be a general. See "Obituary, General Sir F. C. A. Stephenson", ''The Times'', 11 March 1911, p. 11</ref> Stephenson's father became a civil servant, rising to become chairman of the [[Inland Revenue|Board of Inland Revenue]].<ref>"Obituary, Sir William Henry Stephenson", ''The Times'', 2 March 1898, p. 8</ref> The young Stephenson was commissioned into the Middlesex Militia<ref>''[[The Morning Post]]'', 31 October 1857, p. 3</ref> and later entered the civil service.<ref name=obit>"Obituary, Mr. B. C. Stephenson", ''The Times'', 24 January 1906, p. 5</ref>
While working as a civil servant, Stephenson began writing theatrical pieces. His grandfather, General B. C. Stephenson, had lived and died at a house in Bolton Row, [[Mayfair]], and the young Stephenson adopted "Bolton Rowe" as his pen name.<ref name=general/> Stephenson's first works were collaborations with the composer [[Frederic Clay]] in three pieces played by amateurs, ''The Pirate's Isle'', ''Out of Sight'' and ''The Bold Recruit'' (1868). The last of these was repeated at a benefit, produced by [[Thomas German Reed]], at the [[Gallery of Illustration]] in 1870 as a companion piece to Clay and [[W.S. Gilbert]]'s ''[[Ages Ago]]''.<ref>''[[The Era (newspaper)|The Era]]'', 24 July 1870, p. 6</ref> Stephenson's first professional success came at the same venue, two years later, with a short [[operetta]], written with the composer [[Alfred Cellier]], ''Charity Begins at Home''.<ref>Adams, p. 273</ref> The piece was in the company's repertory for most of 1872, and was played more than 200 times.<ref>''The Morning Post'', 16 November 1872, p. 1; and "Dramatic and Musical Chronology for 1872", ''The Era'', 5 January 1873, supplement.</ref>
Stephenson was still using the pseudonym "Bolton Rowe" when he wrote the libretto for [[Arthur Sullivan]]'s one-act [[comic opera]] ''[[The Zoo]]'' in 1875.<ref>''The Era'', 6 June 1875, p. 4</ref> This work is still played today with some frequency.<ref>See, e. g., [http://www.finboroughtheatre.co.uk/archive/archive_agilbertandsullivandoublebill.htm this information about a 2007 Finborough production]; and Sir Arthur Sullivan Society Magazine vol. 66, Winter 2007 p. 5 about the Charles Court Opera production first performed the same year.</ref> He then began a writing partnership with [[Clement Scott]], who adopted the matching pen name, "Saville Rowe" (after [[Savile Row]], another Mayfair street).<ref>"Theatrical Gossip", ''The Era'', 24 September 1876, p. 4</ref> Together, for the [[Squire Bancroft|Bancrofts]] at the [[Scala Theatre|Prince of Wales's Theatre]], they wrote English versions of [[Victorien Sardou]]'s plays, ''Nos intimes'' (as ''Peril'') and ''Dora'' (1878 as ''Diplomacy''). The latter was described by the theatrical paper ''[[The Era (newspaper)|The Era]]'' as "the great dramatic hit of the season".<ref>''The Era'', 23 June 1878, p. 12</ref> It also played with success at [[Wallack's Theatre]] in New York.<ref>"Theatrical Gossip", ''The Era'', 7 April 1878, p. 6</ref> Stephenson and Scott wrote an English version of [[Ludovic Halévy|Halévy]] and [[Henri Meilhac|Meilhac]]'s libretto for [[Charles Lecocq|Lecocq]]'s operette, ''Le Petit Duc''. Their adaptation so pleased the composer that he volunteered to write some new music for the English production.<ref>"Theatrical Gossip", ''The Era'', 28 April 1878, p. 7</ref>
===West End and Broadway success=== In 1880, Stephenson's work again featured in New York. The reopened Broadway Opera House was inaugurated with a double bill of ''Ages Ago'' and ''Charity Begins at Home''.<ref>"The Drama in America", ''The Era'', 28 March 1880, p. 4</ref> Stephenson also supplied the libretto for a three-act [[grand opera]] version of [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow|Longfellow]]'s ''The Masque of Pandora'', composed by Alfred Cellier, and presented in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] in 1881.<ref>"The Drama in America", ''The Era'', 1 August 1880, p. 5</ref> The next year in London, Stephenson collaborated with [[Brandon Thomas]] on a "new and critical comedy", ''Comrades'', for the [[Royal Court Theatre|Court Theatre]], with a cast including [[Arthur Cecil]], [[Dion Boucicault Jr.|D. G. Boucicault]] and [[Marion Terry]].<ref>''The Times'', 19 December 1882, p. 8</ref> Writing under his real name for the first time, Stephenson had a great success in 1882–83 with his play ''Impulse'', based on ''La Maison du mari'' by [[Xavier de Montépin]], which opened in December 1882 and ran through most of the next year.<ref>''The Times'', 1 December 1882, p. 6; and 18 September 1883, p. 6</ref> In 1886, he adapted ''Der Probepfeil'' by [[Oscar Blumenthal]] as ''A Woman of the World'', which was staged at the [[Haymarket Theatre]], starring [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] and [[Helen Barry]].<ref>''Le Follet: Journal du Grand Monde'', 1 February 1886, p. 16.</ref>
In 1886 Stephenson had his greatest success. He and Cellier wrote the [[comic opera]] ''[[Dorothy (opera)|Dorothy]]''. The piece opened at the [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]] on 25 September 1886, receiving lukewarm notices. Much of Cellier's score was reused material from an earlier failure, and neither the music nor the libretto attracted critical praise. ''[[The Times]]'' wrote, "Gentility reigns supreme, and with it unfortunately also a good deal of the refined feebleness and the ineptitude which are the defects of that quality."<ref>''The Times'', 27 September 1886, p. 10</ref> Stephenson and Cellier revised the work, and it transferred in December to the [[Prince of Wales Theatre]] with new stars, including [[Marie Tempest]]. ''Dorothy'' became a great success at the box office and transferred in 1888 to the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]], where it ran until 1889. Its initial run of a total of 931 performances was the longest of any piece of musical theatre up to that time.<ref>Gillan, Don. [http://www.stagebeauty.net/th-frames.html?http&&&www.stagebeauty.net/th-longr.html Longest Running Plays in London and New York, 1875 to 1920] at the Stage Beauty website (2007)</ref> Some critics reconsidered their earlier condemnation, the work became regarded as a classic Victorian piece,<ref>"Dorothy", ''The Times'', 22 December 1908, p. 11</ref> and the initially despised plot was traced seriously back to the Restoration playwrights [[David Garrick]] and [[Aphra Behn]], and to [[Oliver Goldsmith]] and even [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]].<ref>"Things Theatrical", ''[[The Sporting Times]]'', 23 July 1892, p. 2</ref> Stephenson and Cellier later collaborated on another comic opera, ''[[Doris (opera)|Doris]]'' (1888), which, without rivalling ''Dorothy'', had a good run of more than 200 performances.
Stephenson's later work in musical theatre was less successful. For the [[Carl Rosa Opera Company]] he rewrote the libretto for ''The Golden Web'', an [[opera bouffe]] by the composer [[Arthur Goring Thomas]], which was first heard in 1893. In spite of some positive critical attention, interest in the piece was short-lived.<ref>"The Golden Web", ''[[The Musical Times]]'' March 1893, p. 152; and "Facts, Rumours, and Remarks", ''The Musical Times'', January 1893, pp. 18–20</ref> The same year, two short operettas with music by [[Edward Jakobowski]], ''The Improvisatore'' and ''A Venetian Singer'', made little impact.<ref>''The Musical Times'', September 1893, p. 549 and "Things Theatrical", ''The Sporting Times'', 11 November 1893, p. 3</ref> ''The Ranch'', a musical farce with music by [[Edward Solomon]], failed to find a theatre to stage it. A libretto for [[Charles Villiers Stanford]], ''Christopher Patch, The Barber of Bath'', was set by Stanford but has never been performed.<ref>Hudson, Frederick. "C. V. Stanford: Nova Bibliographica", ''The Musical Times'', October 1963, pp. 728–31</ref> A libretto for [[Alexander Mackenzie (composer)|Sir Alexander Mackenzie]] remained, as McKenzie put it in 1898, "still in my desk".<ref>"Alexander Campbell Mackenzie", ''The Musical Times'', June 1898, pp. 369–74</ref>
===Later years=== In the non-musical theatre, Stephenson continued to prosper. By the 1890s he was sufficiently well known that his name as author of a play lent cachet. In 1892 one British newspaper protested that a new play, advertised as the work of Stephenson and [[Augustus Harris]], was in fact the work of less-known writers.<ref>"Things Theatrical", ''The Sporting Times'', 5 March 1892, p. 3</ref> In the same year, Stephenson produced one of his more enduring works, ''Faithful James'', a one act comedy. It supplanted Gilbert's ''[[Rosencrantz and Guildenstern (Gilbert)|Rosencrantz and Guildenstern]]'' in a triple bill running at the Court Theatre. The cast included [[Weedon Grossmith]], Brandon Thomas, [[Ellaline Terriss]] and [[Sybil Grey]].<ref>"Things Theatrical", ''The Sporting Times'', 23 July 1892, p. 2</ref> Among later revivals of the play was one in 1907 with [[Rutland Barrington]] in the title role of the bumbling butler.<ref>"Coronet Theatre", ''The Times'', 23 July 1907, p. 5</ref> In 1894, Stephenson co-wrote a melodrama with [[Charles Haddon Chambers|Haddon Chambers]], ''The Fatal Card'', which was well received.<ref>"Adelphi Theatre: ''The Fatal Card''", ''The Sporting Times'', 8 September 1894, p. 6</ref> Asked how he and his collaborator worked together, he said, "We divide the labour. I write all the vowels and Mr Chambers all the consonants."<ref>''The Sporting Times'', 15 September 1894, p. 3</ref>
Among revivals of Stephenson's works, during his life and after, were ''Dorothy'' (on several occasions, notably in 1908, when the critic of ''The Times'' called it "one of the most tuneful, most charming, and most shapely of English comic operas") and ''Diplomacy'', which was given in command performances for [[Queen Victoria]] in 1893 and [[George V]] in 1914,<ref>"The Theatres: The Command Performance of ''Diplomacy'', " ''The Times'', 24 January 1914 p. 6</ref> and was revived again in 1924, starring [[Gladys Cooper]].<ref>"The Theatres: Miss Gladys Cooper's New Part: Revival of ''Diplomacy''", ''The Times'', 11 February 1924, p. 10</ref>
Stephenson died in [[Taplow]], [[Berkshire]], at the age of 66.<ref name=obit/>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *Adams, William Davenport. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TzwOAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Arthur+Cecil%22+blunt&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''A Dictionary of the Drama''], Chatto & Windus, 1904
==External links== *[http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/british/authors/stephenson.html Profile of Stephenson] *[http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/british/dorothy/index.html Site with information about ''Dorothy''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060901175547/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/british/musicals.html Information about stage works] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060629161134/http://halhkmusic.com/doris.html Midis and lyrics for Doris]
{{Authority control}}

C.}} [[Category:English opera librettists]] [[Category:People associated with Gilbert and Sullivan]] [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1906 deaths]] [[Category:English male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:19th-century British dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:19th-century British male writers]] [[Category:19th-century English writers]]

{{Infobox film | name = Between Hitler and Stalin | image = Between hitler and stalin film.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Slavko Nowytski]] | producer = [[Slavko Nowytski]] | writer = [[Kristi Wheeler]] | starring = | music = | story = [[Wsevolod W. Isajiw]] | narrator = [[Jack Palance]] | editing = | distributor = [[Ukrainian Canadian Research and Documentation Centre]] | released = {{Film date|2003| | |Canada}} | runtime = 60 minutes | country = [[Canada]]
[[Ukraine]] | language = [[English language|English]]
[[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] | budget = }} '''''Between Hitler and Stalin: Ukraine in World War II''''' is a 2003 film produced and directed by [[Slavko Nowytski]] and narrated by [[Jack Palance]]. The one-hour documentary, part black-and-white and part color, is a project of [[Ukrainian Canadian Research and Documentation Centre]] – an attempt to tell the story of [[World War II]] from a [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] perspective. In a chronological manner, Nowytski's film unfolds during the years of [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Soviet–Nazi collaboration]] recounting the losses and suffering of the Ukrainian people; the documentary shifts to the destruction wrought by [[Joseph Stalin]]'s scorched earth policy as the [[Soviet Union military]] retreated, and shows the ruins left behind by the German and then the Soviet offensives.Zakydalsky, Oksana. [http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/2003/450303.shtml Documentary "Between Hitler and Stalin" offers untold story of Ukraine] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930033316/http://www.ukrweekly.com/Archive/2003/450303.shtml |date=September 30, 2007}}. ''The Ukrainian Weekly''. 9 November 2003, No. 45, Vol. LXXI. ''Between Hitler and Stalin'' describes the activity of the underground resistance movements, and specifically the long and large-scale struggle of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] (UPA) on two fronts, against both totalitarian powers, for [[Ukraine]]'s independence. As Oksana Zakydalsky writes for ''[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]'': "although [World War II is] often called the Russo-German war or described as Russia at war, only parts of Russia were occupied, while all Ukrainian territories were invaded and laid waste by both the Nazi and Soviet war machines. ... The film documents Ukraine's contribution to the war against totalitarianism and the price Ukraine paid for its independence." For historical and political commentary, the film relies on [[Norman Davies]], a historian from [[University of London]]; [[Robert Conquest]], a Soviet scholar at [[Hoover Institute]]; John Armstrong, an insurgency expert, and [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]], a former US National Security Adviser. == References == [[Category:2003 films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language films]] [[Category:Canadian documentary films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Soviet Union in the Stalin era]] [[Category:Films about World War II resistance movements]] [[Category:Documentary films about genocide]] [[Category:Documentary films about World War II]] [[Category:Documentary films about Ukraine]] {{Ukraine-film-stub}} {{war-documentary-film-stub}}

[[Image:Bezold Effect.svg|frame|right|Demonstration of the Bezold effect. The red seems lighter combined with the white, and darker combined with the black.]] The '''Bezold effect''' is an [[optical illusion]], named after a German professor of meteorology, [[Wilhelm von Bezold]] (1837–1907), who discovered that a color may appear different depending on its relation to adjacent colors.
It happens when small areas of color are interspersed. An assimilation effect called the '''von Bezold spreading effect''', similar to [[spatial color mixing]], is achieved.
The opposite effect is observed when large areas of color are placed adjacent to each other, resulting in [[color contrast]].
==References== *Albers, J. ''Interaction of color'': unabridged text and selected plates. 8. ed. Massachusetts: Yale University Press, 1978. *Echo Productions. ''Wilhelm von Bezold''. Virtual color museum. Available at: [https://web.archive.org/web/20090304122649/http://www.colorsystem.com/projekte/engl/22beze.htm http://www.colorsystem.com/projekte/engl/22beze.htm]. *Bergantini, Ernesto: ''Farbe im Design. Basiswissen'', Gossau, 2010, p. 115.
{{Optical illusions}}
[[Category:Optical illusions]] [[Category:Color]] [[Category:Visual perception]]
{{optics-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Parzival und Condviramur.jpg|thumb|200px|fol. 135r]]
The '''Cod. Pal. germ. 339''' ([[Bibliotheca Palatina|CPG]] 339) is an illustrated manuscript of [[Wolfram von Eschenbach]]'s ''[[Parzival]]'', created in [[Hagenau]] in the 1440s in the workshop of [[Diebold Lauber]].
==External links== *[http://digi.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/sammlung1/cpg/cpg339i.xml?docname=cpg339i&pageid=PAGE0001 facsimile]
